data.definition: Raw facts or measurements collected from sources.
data.explanation: Data alone has no meaning until processed or analyzed.
data.interview_tip: Explain difference between data and information.

information.explanation: Information helps decision making after analysis.

dataset.explanation: Datasets are used for analysis and machine learning.

structured data.definition: Data organized in rows and columns.

python.definition: Programming language widely used in data science.

variable.explanation: Used to store numbers, text, or objects.

tuple.explanation: Used when data should not change.

scatter plot.definition: Plot showing relationship between two variables.

sql.definition: SQL is a language used to manage and query relational databases.
sql.explanation: It allows users to retrieve, insert, update and delete structured data.
sql.interview_tip: Explain SQL as Structured Query Language.

sql select.explanation: SELECT specifies which columns to return.

sql insert.definition: Adds new rows into a table.

sql update.interview_tip: Warn about updating all rows accidentally.

inner join.definition: Returns matching records from both tables.
inner join.explanation: Rows must exist in both tables.

left join.definition: Returns all rows from left table.

right join.definition: Returns all rows from right table.

full join.definition: Returns all rows from both tables.

index.explanation: Creates lookup table for faster search.

etl.explanation: Moves data from source to warehouse.

star schema.definition: Warehouse design using fact and dimension tables.

data visualization.explanation: Helps users understand patterns and trends quickly.
data visualization.interview_tip: Explain why visuals improve decision making.

bar chart.definition: Chart using bars to compare values.

scatter plot.definition: Plot showing relationship between two variables.

dashboard.definition: Collection of visuals on one screen.

tableau.explanation: Creates dashboards using drag and drop.

tableau action filter.definition: Interactive filter triggered by user action.

power query.definition: Data transformation tool in Power BI.

power bi dashboard.definition: Collection of visuals pinned to one page.

machine learning.definition: Machine learning enables systems to learn patterns from data.
machine learning.explanation: Instead of writing rules manually, models learn relationships between inputs and outputs.
machine learning.interview_tip: Explain ML as learning from examples.

supervised learning.explanation: Model learns mapping from input to output.

random forest.explanation: Combines multiple trees to improve accuracy.

naive bayes.definition: Probabilistic classifier based on Bayes theorem.

feature engineering.definition: Creating new features from raw data.

one hot encoding.definition: Converts categorical values into binary columns.

f1 score.definition: Harmonic mean of precision and recall.

semantic search.definition: Search based on meaning rather than keywords.

deep learning.definition: Subset of machine learning using neural networks with multiple layers.
deep learning.explanation: Deep learning models learn complex patterns from large datasets.
deep learning.interview_tip: Explain difference between ML and DL.

neural network.explanation: Consists of layers of nodes learning weighted relationships.

cnn.explanation: Uses filters to extract spatial features.

transformer architecture.definition: Deep learning architecture based on attention.

fine tuning.definition: Adapting pretrained model to new task.

knowledge distillation.definition: Training small model from large model.

concept drift.definition: Change in relationship between input and output.

api inference.explanation: Users send requests to get results.

top k sampling.definition: Sampling from top k probable tokens.

chatbot.definition: Software system that simulates conversation with users.
chatbot.explanation: Uses NLP and machine learning to understand queries and provide responses.
chatbot.interview_tip: Explain difference between rule-based and AI chatbots.

intent recognition.definition: Process of identifying user intention from text.
intent recognition.explanation: Used to classify what the user wants.

slot filling.example: Booking system asking date and time.

fallback response.definition: Default reply when chatbot cannot understand.

context window.definition: Amount of conversation history model can process.
context window.explanation: Defines how much past text is remembered.

sentence transformers.explanation: Used for semantic search and similarity.

reranking.definition: Reordering search results using advanced models.

chunking strategy.definition: Splitting large documents into smaller pieces.

shap values.definition: Feature attribution method based on game theory.

partial dependence plot.definition: Shows effect of feature on prediction.

mann whitney test.explanation: Used when data not normally distributed.
